author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Rescue of Troubled Trucking Company With White House Ties Draws Scrutiny
description: Members of a congressional oversight panel want to know how YRC Worldwide won a $700 million loan from the Treasury Department.
content: WASHINGTON — At a virtual congressional hearing in May, Senator Jerry Moran, Republican of Kansas, asked Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin for help. A struggling trucking company in his state was on the brink of collapse and needed government support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib
title: Abductions, Censorship and Layoffs: Pakistani Critics Are Under Siege
description: Recent abductions of a journalist and an activist have underscored Pakistan’s worsening rights conditions as the country’s security forces pressure the news media and human rights groups.
content: When Prime Minister Imran Khan boasted last year that Pakistan had one of the “freest presses in the world,” journalists were quick to object, saying that intimidation of reporters across the country was intensifying. It has only gotten worse since.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Attacking Mail-In Voting, Trump Suggests Rerunning a New York Race
description: Former President Barack Obama endorsed 118 candidates, hoping to tip the scales in key battlegrounds. Primary races in several states on Tuesday have the attention of national party leaders.
content: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: A Historic Supreme Court Ruling Upends Courts in Oklahoma
description: Local prosecutors are referring criminal cases to the federal and tribal courts, which are now flooded with new cases.
content: TULSA, Okla. — Kelsey Lipp was sitting in jail, charged with robbery and murder, when her lawyer walked into court with three pieces of paper and a new plan to get her case thrown out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Strange Saga of TikTok
description: The chief executive of a big tech company negotiated directly with the U.S. president over an app. Say what?
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: These Conservatives Have a Laser Focus: ‘Owning the Libs’
description: On The Federalist and in Fox News appearances, some of President Trump’s supporters don’t really defend him. They attack the critics.
content: When President Trump ran for office four years ago, a conservative writer with a growing following vented the kind of doubt and cynicism that was common among people like her who worried about the damage he could do to their cause. She called him “a demagogue with no real solutions for anything at all.” She accused him of betraying the anti-abortion movement. And she wrote that his constant complaining about being treated unfairly was “ineffectual and impotent.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Is Riding the Subway Safer Than Dining Indoors?
description: In major global cities where the pandemic has ebbed, it appears that public transportation may not be as risky as nervous New Yorkers believe.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Trump Puts Pentagon in Political Crossfire With Tata Appointment
description: The president sidestepped Congress when it became clear that his nominee for a top Defense Department position would not win Senate approval.
content: WASHINGTON — In making an end run around Congress to appoint Anthony J. Tata, a retired brigadier general with a history of Islamophobic and other inflammatory views, to a top Defense Department post, President Trump has once again put the military exactly where it does not want to be: in the middle of a political battle that could hurt bipartisan support for the Pentagon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Perry Mason’ Season 1, Episode 7: Resurrection Sunday
description: As Perry gathers evidence, a clearer picture of Baby Charlie’s fate emerges. Meanwhile, the moment of truth arrives for Emily and Sister Alice.
content: “I am fighting — for a woman’s life!” Perry Mason yells at his friend and partner Pete Strickland. “I can’t lose, Pete! I can’t [expletive] this up like … ”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: The Benefits of Talking to Strangers
description: Casual connections with people we encounter in the course of daily life can give us the sense of belonging to a community.
content: I’m a lifelong extrovert who readily establishes and relishes casual contacts with people I encounter during daily life: while walking my dog, shopping for groceries, working out at the Y, even sweeping my sidewalk. These ephemeral connections add variety to my life, are a source of useful information and often provide needed emotional and physical support. Equally important, they nearly always leave me with a smile on my face (although now hidden under a mask!).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Why the Botched N.Y.C. Primary Has Become the November Nightmare
description: Nearly six weeks later, two congressional races remain undecided, and officials are trading blame over the mishandling of tens of thousands of mail-in ballots.
content: Election officials in New York City widely distributed mail-in ballots for the primary on June 23, which featured dozens of hard-fought races. The officials had hoped to make voting much easier, but they did not seem prepared for the response: more than 10 times the number of absentee ballots received in recent elections in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Microsoft Can Save TikTok — if Trump Doesn’t Mess It Up
description: Microsoft wants to buy the Chinese app, and the administration needs to get out of the way.
content: Yes, President Trump can ban TikTok in the United States. The problem? This won’t actually stop the digital deluge from China.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Selfishness in American Society Today
description: Readers, responding to a column by Paul Krugman, discuss whether selfishness crosses party lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Good News About What Human Genius Can Still Do
description: There’s something uniquely compelling about our need to learn what we can about the universe.
content: We may never solve the puzzle of Stonehenge, and, if we do, it probably won’t change our lives. Nor will much change if the latest American robot zooming toward Mars discovers that eons ago microorganisms swam in long vanished lakes. Yet how gloriously enthralling the search!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Dwayne Johnson Part of XFL Ownership Bid
description: The actor and former wrestler, who is known as the Rock, is part of a group of investors that bought what remains of the XFL for $15 million, pending bankruptcy court approval.
content: In the early days of the coronavirus pandemic, the XFL football league shut up shop, just five weeks into its ballyhooed restart. Then it filed for bankruptcy. It seemed like an abrupt, but final, end for the revived league, which first rose to notoriety for a single season 19 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: Share Your Medical Bills for Coronavirus
description: As we explore how the pandemic is changing U.S. health care, you can help by showing what you’re being charged for testing and treatment.
content: Have a bill you want to share? Go straight to the form.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Marathon Is Selling Speedway Gas Stations to 7-Eleven’s Parent for $21 Billion
description: The largest U.S. independent refining company will get cash, and 7-Eleven will add 4,000 convenience stores.
content: HOUSTON — Marathon Petroleum, the largest U.S. independent refiner, announced on Sunday that it had sold its Speedway gas station chain to the Japanese retail group Seven & I Holdings for $21 billion in cash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: In Showdown Between China and the West, HSBC Gets Caught in the Middle
description: Global businesses are increasingly being asked to pick political and legal sides in the confrontation between the world’s two biggest economies.
content: HONG KONG — Like Hong Kong, HSBC has long sat at the crossroads between East and West, a big global bank based in Britain that has reveled in and profited from its deep relationship with China. And like Hong Kong, it is now caught in the middle of a new era of confrontation between Beijing and major Western governments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chuck Lovell
title: I’m the Police Chief in Portland. Violence Isn’t the Answer.
description: As a Black man and a public servant, I see that spectacle is drowning out the voices that need to be heard to make positive change.
content: After the horrendous killing of George Floyd, people in Portland, Ore., joined with thousands across the country in demonstrations to address police reform and widespread systemic racism. The leaders of the Portland Police Bureau denounced this tragic death, and we reiterated our willingness to engage in reforms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: How to Ace an Online Job Interview
description: A handful of classic techniques and some tips unique to the work-from-home era can help you land that next job.
content: The in-person job interview went away when offices emptied this spring because of the coronavirus pandemic. On the plus side, no more flying out to company headquarters and staying at a hotel, just to spend a day of meetings in an uncomfortable suit and then heading right back home. On the downside, common technical snafus and fewer body language clues can make the online process feel fraught. To successfully make the jump to team member from virtual job seeker, brush up on classic interview techniques and adapt them to the new world of internet interviews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Automated Line Calls Will Replace Human Judges at U.S. Open
description: On all but the two biggest show courts, line calls will be made by Hawk-Eye Live to reduce the number of people on site during the pandemic.
content: Three weeks of World TeamTennis at the Greenbrier resort in West Virginia had come down to a single point on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: After 100 Podcasts, JJ Redick Widens His Range
description: The New Orleans Pelicans shooter is starting a new show and a production company to develop more podcasts.
content: JJ Redick of the New Orleans Pelicans came prepared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zabihullah Ghazi and Mujib Mashal
title: 29 Dead After ISIS Attack on Afghan Prison
description: The 20-hour gun battle left officials scrambling to recapture hundreds of prisoners, including many from the Islamic State and the Taliban.
content: JALALABAD, Afghanistan — A militant assault on a prison complex in eastern Afghanistan ended on Monday after a 20-hour gun battle, leaving 29 people dead and officials scrambling to recapture hundreds of prisoners, including many from the Islamic State and the Taliban.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Mike Isaac
title: Trump Reverses Course on TikTok, Opening Door to Microsoft Bid
description: The president said he did not object to a potential acquisition of the Chinese-owned app, retreating from comments about banning the service.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump gave the go-ahead for Microsoft to pursue an acquisition of TikTok, in his first public comments about the popular Chinese-owned video app after he had threatened to ban it from the United States entirely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian
title: The business news to watch in the week ahead.
description: 🤝 American lawmakers are haggling over a new stimulus bill, with the shape of supplemental jobless benefits — which expired last week — the biggest sticking point. Democrats are pushing for a $3 trillion package that extends many of the previous measures, while Republicans have aimed for a narrower bill worth around $1 trillion.
content: 🤝 American lawmakers are haggling over a new stimulus bill, with the shape of supplemental jobless benefits — which expired last week — the biggest sticking point. Democrats are pushing for a $3 trillion package that extends many of the previous measures, while Republicans have aimed for a narrower bill worth around $1 trillion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian Friedman
title: Men’s Wearhouse Owner Files for Bankruptcy
description: Tailored Brands, known for its clothing chains Men’s Wearhouse and JoS. A. Bank, struggled as the pandemic shut stores and consumer demand for office attire dropped.
content: The owner of Men’s Wearhouse and JoS. A. Bank, which once dominated the market for affordable men’s suits, filed for bankruptcy protection late Sunday, as demand plummeted for its corporate clothing with the coronavirus pandemic keeping America’s office workers at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: Sotheby’s Reports $2.5 Billion in Sales
description: The auction house says that figure reflects a “resilient” market amid the coronavirus. But it represents a 25 percent decrease in auction sales, analysts say.
content: Sotheby’s, the international auction house bought in 2019 by the telecommunications magnate Patrick Drahi, reported Monday that it has sold $2.5 billion of art and collectibles so far this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: As the Virus Spreads Through M.L.B., So Does Frustration
description: Series have been postponed, teams have been quarantined and road trips have been rerouted in a season that has been defined above all by its precariousness.
content: Major League Baseball is like a beleaguered landlord with 30 frightened tenants. Flooding in one apartment damages several others. The pipes get fixed, and then mold spreads in the room down the hall. Nobody wants to condemn the building, but everyone knows it might collapse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Venture fund-raising is alive and (relatively) well.
description: The coronavirus has made it more difficult for entrepreneurs to raise money. But for many companies — from established businesses to smaller start-ups — the pandemic hasn’t prevented them from finding investors willing to open their wallets.
content: The coronavirus has made it more difficult for entrepreneurs to raise money. But for many companies — from established businesses to smaller start-ups — the pandemic hasn’t prevented them from finding investors willing to open their wallets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Emily Cochrane and Jim Tankersley
title: With Jobless Aid Expired, Trump Sidelines Himself in Stimulus Talks
description: As his top advisers met with Democratic leaders to try to hash out a compromise, President Trump hurled insults at Democrats and mused aloud about short-circuiting the talks and acting on his own.
content: On the first day of the first full week when tens of millions of Americans went without the federal jobless aid that has cushioned them during the pandemic, President Trump was not cajoling undecided lawmakers to embrace a critical stimulus bill to stabilize the foundering economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: There Are Two Ways Out of a Frog. This Beetle Chose the Back Door.
description: A researcher fed beetles to frogs. The encounter did not end as expected.
content: It’s a familiar story: Predator hunts prey. Predator catches prey. Predator gulps down prey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: TikTok, Coronavirus, Spearfishing: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum and Benjamin Weiser
title: D.A. Is Investigating Trump and His Company Over Fraud, Filing Suggests
description: The office of the district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., made the disclosure in a new court filing arguing Mr. Trump’s accountants should turn over his tax returns.
content: The Manhattan district attorney’s office suggested on Monday that it had been investigating President Trump and his company for possible bank and insurance fraud, a significantly broader inquiry than the prosecutors have acknowledged in the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Drew
title: Let’s Scrap the Presidential Debates
description: They’ve become unrevealing quip contests.
content: Nervous managers of the scheduled 2020 presidential debates are shuffling the logistics and locations to deal with the threat of the coronavirus. But here’s a better idea: Scrap them altogether. And not for health reasons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Is Telemedicine Here to Stay?
description: The answer largely depends on whether Medicare and private health insurers will adequately cover virtual doctor visits once coronavirus outbreaks subside.
content: Telemedicine is having its moment. Over the last few months, millions of people have relied on video or telephone calls to talk to their doctors. But as the pandemic moves across the United States, and eventually recedes in some places, how long will the moment last?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: F.T.C. Investigating Twitter for Potential Privacy Violations
description: The social media company said the agency was examining whether it had misused people’s personal information to serve ads.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — Twitter said on Monday that it was under investigation by the Federal Trade Commission for potentially misusing people’s personal information to serve ads, adding that it faced fines of $150 million to $250 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Juan Carlos, Spain’s Former King, Quits Country Amid Multiple Investigations
description: The former king’s departure, which comes as he faces financial inquiries, may fuel Spain’s political and social debate over the future of the monarchy.
content: The former king of Spain, Juan Carlos, announced on Monday he was abandoning his country amid a Spanish court investigation into a lucrative business contract and a separate money laundering and tax evasion probe in Switzerland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Why One Team Named the Indians Won’t Be Changing Its Name
description: A minor league team in Spokane, Wash., has steadfastly stood by its nickname with the support of the local Native American community.
content: Many sports teams using names and mascots invoking Native Americans do so over the longstanding and strenuous objections of people who say it is racist. Some teams, after years of stubborn refusal, have recently relented, like the Washington Football Team of the N.F.L., which abandoned its nickname last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Disenchanted Seniors for Biden
description: The pandemic is particularly dangerous for older Americans, and Trump is losing their support.
content: The ad opens with amateur footage of an older, white-haired woman, smiling and chatting with the toddler snuggled in her lap. In a voice-over, a younger woman reminisces about how her grandmother’s home had always been “the safe place.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Keyssar
title: How Has the Electoral College Survived for This Long?
description: Resistance to eliminating it has long been connected to the idea of white supremacy.
content: As our revived national conversation on race has made clear, the legacies of slavery and white supremacy run wide and deep in American society and political life. One such legacy — which is particularly noteworthy in a presidential election season — has been the survival and preservation of the Electoral College, an institution that has been under fire for more than 200 years. Our complicated method of electing presidents has been the target of recurrent reform attempts since the early 19th century, and the politics of race and region have figured prominently in their defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Ja Morant’s Dunks Are Amazing. His Misses Are Even Better.
description: Morant, the star rookie for the Memphis Grizzlies, has become known for dunking over any and everyone. “He really doesn’t care who’s down there,” a teammate said.
content: Ja Morant of the Memphis Grizzlies had already spent several months showcasing his hops when he and his teammates faced the Los Angeles Lakers in February. By then, Morant’s willingness to challenge some of the N.B.A.’s most towering figures was no secret.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wrongfully Accused by an Algorithm
description: In what may be the first known case of its kind, a faulty facial recognition match led to a Michigan man’s arrest for a crime he did not commit.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Trump Again Assails Mail-In Voting
description: The president has been raging against voting by mail for several months, claiming without evidence that the process is plagued by fraud.
content: WASHINGTON — In his latest assault on voting by mail, President Trump said on Monday that he thought the Democratic primary in New York’s 12th Congressional District should be rerun because of lengthy delays in counting mail-in ballots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Gray
title: Rashida Tlaib Beat Her Primary Opponent by 900 Votes in 2018. How Will the Rematch Go?
description: The Michigan Democrat is facing a rematch against a challenger who says she hasn’t done enough for her district in Detroit.
content: DETROIT — Representative Rashida Tlaib, a first-term Michigan Democrat who rocketed to national attention as a vocal critic of President Trump, is fighting for her political life, locked in a close primary race that could be decided by a few hundred mail-in ballots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Dynarski
title: The United States Is Reopening Many of the Wrong Schools
description: When it is safe enough to return to school, young children would benefit the most. Yet financial pressures are pushing colleges to reopen most rapidly, an economist says.
content: With coronavirus cases spiking in dozens of states, the prospect of anything resembling a normal school year is fading fast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Marcus Samuelsson’s Streetbird Delivers to Your Door
description: The closed Harlem restaurant now offers a dinner of fried chicken, waffles and sides.
content: The chef Marcus Samuelsson’s Streetbird flies again. His closed Harlem restaurant specialized in fried chicken, and the dish is now available for delivery nationwide. All it requires is a quick reheat. In the kit, which serves four, you get four battered, golden-brown back-quarters (legs and thighs) with cornbread waffles, pickles and hot honey for drizzling (a desirable enhancement) and a mixed vegetable succotash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift’s ‘Folklore’ Is No. 1 With a Blockbuster Debut Week
description: The singer and songwriter’s surprise album had the equivalent of 846,000 sales in the United States, a total beaten only by her own last two LPs.
content: A new Taylor Swift album usually arrives with a monthslong marketing rollout: radio singles, corporate tie-ins, a string of media appearances — all carefully choreographed to send her to No. 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller and Jill Cowan
title: The Last California County Without a Coronavirus Case
description: Monday: The virus found its way into tiny, remote Modoc County. Also: The Apple Fire prompted evacuations, and a successful astronaut return.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Trump Doesn’t Like What He Sees in the Crystal Ball
description: Besides delaying the election, what else could alter his political trajectory?
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, some of our readers may not know that, in addition to all of your journalism at The Times, you’re also the author of several distinguished works of history. Put on your historian’s hat and tell us what you think of Donald Trump’s tweet suggesting we delay the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: These Remarks Might Get a Police Chief Fired. Not in New York.
description: The police commissioner’s pointed criticism — and the fact that he still has his job — speaks to the mayor’s fraught relationship with the Police Department.
content: The criticism of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s law enforcement policies was stinging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard J. Samuels
title: Why the U.S. Dropped Atomic Bombs on Japan
description: Marc Gallicchio’s “Unconditional” details debates in both Japan and the United States to end World War II.
content: UNCONDITIONALThe Japanese Surrender in World War IIBy Marc Gallicchio
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: The (Virtual) Theatrical Fringe Moves Front and Center
description: Expanding content and experimenting with form, the avant-garde finds a congenial new home online, as two recent offerings demonstrate.
content: As the pandemic has sent most art forms scurrying into mole holes, some have had to adapt more than others. In the theater, the change has been especially pronounced, amounting to a complete upside-down flip: Big players can’t squeeze themselves into the new accommodations, but little ones feel right at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Gettysburg? The Liberty Bell? Trump Weighs R.N.C. Speech Options
description: The president and his aides are holding out hope for ambitious convention programming, and have considered a return to Mount Rushmore or a speech by Melania Trump from Seneca Falls, N.Y.
content: WASHINGTON — A presidential address in front of the Gettysburg battlefield, or at the Liberty Bell in Philadelphia. A speech from the first lady, Melania Trump, at Seneca Falls, N.Y., the cradle of the national movement for women’s rights. Perhaps a stage for the warm-up acts built at the Trump International Hotel in Washington, D.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Kansas Senate Primary Has Arrived, and the Anxiety Over Kobach Is High
description: Republicans worry that if Kris Kobach, a polarizing figure in the state, wins the nomination, it would pave the way for Democrats to capture the seat and perhaps gain control of the Senate.
content: Republican anxieties about control of the Senate are reaching new heights this week as the Kansas Senate primary hurdles to a close, amid fears in Washington that the firebrand candidate and staunch Trump supporter Kris Kobach could win the nomination but lose a longtime red seat in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Horchata Ice Cream in a Store Near You
description: Helados La Neta is High Road Craft’s new line of flavors including coconut, avocado and lime, and rum raisin.
content: This has been the summer of new ice creams. I suppose that when you’re sheltering in place, there’s nothing more tempting than a pint and a spoon. A line of inviting Mexican-inspired flavors called Helados La Neta has been introduced by High Road Craft, a bakery and ice cream company in Marietta, Ga. (The company also makes Ciao Bella.) Among the offerings are a distinctive vanilla; cinnamon-scented horchata; deep chocolate; nubbly coconut; delicate strawberries and cream; rum raisin; and avocado and lime. The ice creams are sold at Walmart, ShopRite and Kroger stores, among others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: What Is It Like to Watch Live Dance Again? Amazing
description: Kaatsbaan hosts a welcome summer festival in the Hudson Valley, where nature and dancers join forces to put on a show.
content: TIVOLI, N.Y. — It didn’t bode well that the first live dance I was going to see since mid-March was one I had seen many times before. “Sunshine,” a Larry Keigwin war horse set to the Bill Withers’s classic “Ain’t No Sunshine,” can give a dancer the opportunity to really feel the music in all the worst ways. It’s treacly stuff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Judge Whose Son Was Killed by Misogynistic Lawyer Speaks Out
description: “Two weeks ago, my life as I knew it changed in an instant, and my family will never be the same,” Judge Esther Salas said in a video statement.
content: The federal judge whose son was killed by a misogynistic lawyer spoke out Monday for the first time about the shooting, describing the horror that unfolded as her only child ran to answer the door and a “madman” opened fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: John Hume, Nobel Laureate for Work in Northern Ireland, Dies at 83
description: The politician’s campaign for peace was seen as a driving force behind an end to 25 years of sectarian conflict in the territory.
content: John Hume, a moderate Roman Catholic politician who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his dogged and ultimately successful campaign to end decades of bloodshed in his native Northern Ireland, died on Monday in the northern city of Derry. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Why Biden Won’t Find His Biden
description: He would be wise to remember that Barack Obama didn’t pick him simply because they were “simpatico.”
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Trump Pick for Pentagon Post Sidesteps Senate Ire for Different Defense Job
description: A retired Army general whose inflammatory comments appeared to doom his nomination was tapped for a job that does not require Senate approval.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s choice to fill the Pentagon’s top policy job withdrew his name from consideration on Sunday after senators from both parties voiced opposition to the official’s nomination, largely because of his history of inflammatory comments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: Providers: How Has Covid-19 Changed Your Practice?
description: We want to hear from health care providers in the U.S. about how the pandemic has changed work.
content: [If you are a patient, go here.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lina Mounzer
title: We Lebanese Thought We Could Survive Anything. We Were Wrong.
description: The myth of their resilience helped the Lebanese function despite a miserably corrupt and inept state. No longer.
content: BEIRUT — Anyone who knows Lebanon has heard this: The Lebanese are resilient. A reputation earned by weathering an outsize list of challenges over the years: a 15-year civil war, political tensions with Syria, wars with Israel and a collapsing public service infrastructure.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Fauci Supports Birx’s Coronavirus Assessment After Trump Criticizes Her
description: Counting for the 2020 census will end on Sept. 30, a month earlier than previously announced, the Census Bureau said. Some U.S. schools have begun to reopen, with fraught results.
content: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease specialist, agreed on Monday with his colleague Dr. Deborah Birx that the United States has entered a “new phase” of the coronavirus pandemic, in which the virus is now spreading uncontrolled in some states by asymptomatic people — comments that drew fire from President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Michael D. Shear
title: TikTok, Trump and an Impulse to Act as C.E.O. to Corporate America
description: The president’s interventions in company dealings based on his own instincts are a departure from the arm’s-length approach of predecessors of either party.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump campaigned on a promise to run the economy like his business empire. And for almost four years, he has unabashedly wielded the power of the presidency to insert himself into corporate affairs, helping some companies and punishing others in line with his instincts and inclinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: A College Athlete Calls His Coach to Opt Out. And Ends Up on the Outs.
description: Kassidy Woods, a redshirt sophomore receiver at Washington State, was concerned about the pandemic. The coach was sympathetic until he learned he was joining a players’ rights initiative.
content: College athletes have begun challenging a longstanding pillar, that the college sports industrial complex must hum along — as if straight from the pages of “Das Kapital” — on the fuel of exploited labor. Their labor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Hiltner and Phaedra Brown
title: Letting Their Cameras Transport You
description: With some of the finest photojournalists as your guide, The World Through a Lens series offers immersive escapes.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3 Million Homes in California
description: A Spanish-style retreat in Coronado, a midcentury-modern home in Piedmont and a remodeled 1953 house in Los Angeles.
content: Coronado, which sits on a peninsula in San Diego Bay, is known for its historic homes and resorts like the Hotel del Coronado, about five minutes by car from this property. The house, designed in the Spanish Colonial Revival style, is listed on the city’s register of Historic Resources and has a number of intact original features.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: ‘The Biggest Monster’ Is Spreading. And It’s Not the Coronavirus.
description: Tuberculosis kills 1.5 million people each year. Lockdowns and supply-chain disruptions threaten progress against the disease as well as H.I.V. and malaria.
content: It begins with a mild fever and malaise, followed by a painful cough and shortness of breath. The infection prospers in crowds, spreading to people in close reach. Containing an outbreak requires contact tracing, as well as isolation and treatment of the sick for weeks or months.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Senator Dianne Feinstein: Extending a Nuclear Arms Treaty
description: The California senator urges the United States to renew the New Start agreement. Also: Covid test results; disinfecting classrooms.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: The Challenge: Finding a Roommate During a Pandemic
description: With social distancing required, two new roommates discovered, it’s a little like marrying someone before you meet.
content: Most people spent the spring trying to stay as far away from strangers as possible. But for renters like Elizabeth Merritt and Michael Daly, who needed to find roommates in the midst of the pandemic, moving in with someone they had never met was part of the reality of living in New York, global health crisis or not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Afua Hirsch
title: Morgan Jerkins Heads Down South in Search of Her Black Identity
description: “Wandering in Strange Lands” traces the author’s ancestry — and the history of African-American oppression — along the footsteps of the Great Migration.
content: WANDERING IN STRANGE LANDS A Daughter of the Great Migration Reclaims Her Roots By Morgan Jerkins
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed official says a ‘hard’ lockdown could get virus under control.
description: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis suggested that it would be better for the economy if authorities across the United States reinstated lockdowns to bring the spread of the coronavirus under control.
content: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis suggested that it would be better for the economy if authorities across the United States reinstated lockdowns to bring the spread of the coronavirus under control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Immigration Nation’ and ‘Dora and the Lost City of Gold’
description: A six-part docu-series about the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency is on Netflix. And a live-action adaptation of “Dora” arrives on Hulu.
content: IMMIGRATION NATION Stream on Netflix. Leaders of the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency granted behind-the-scenes access to Christina Clusiau and Shaul Schwarz to film this documentary series in 2017. But the filmmakers claim that when the project was nearly completed, government officials fought to censor it and delay its release. (Jenny L. Burke, the ICE press secretary, has disputed the accuracy of these statements.) Now viewers can see for themselves, in the six-part series that offers a candid look at the agency’s operations and tells the stories of some of the immigrants involved. “Part of what makes the film unique is that the creators were allowed not only to enter certain detention facilities but to interview people inside and then follow their cases through the labyrinthine immigration system,” The New York Times reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Lucy Tompkins
title: East Coast Braces for Floods and Wind as Isaias Intensifies
description: A heavy soaking is expected in the Carolinas and Maryland, with tropical storm warnings and watches in effect all the way up the Eastern Seaboard.
content: ATLANTA — Tens of millions of Americans were warned on Monday to brace themselves for the threat of flooding, power outages and downed trees as Hurricane Isaias intensified while moving up the Atlantic Coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: Facebook Bets Big on Future of N.Y.C., and Offices, With New Lease
description: Despite the pandemic, the social media giant leased all the office space in the former main post office at Penn Station in Midtown.
content: Facebook on Monday agreed to lease all the office space in the mammoth 107-year-old James A. Farley Building in Midtown Manhattan, cementing New York City as a growing global technology hub and reaffirming a major corporation’s commitment to an office-centric urban culture despite the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: With TikTok, ‘Uncool’ Microsoft Aims for the Love of Tweens
description: Buying one of the largest and most influential social networks in the country could change the perception of the tech giant.
content: SEATTLE — Maybe money can buy love. Or, at least, Microsoft would like to find out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.C. Shilton
title: Can’t Find It at the Store?
description: How to make sure everyone gets what they need — and feels good about it.
content: When the coronavirus pandemic hit, Kate Coffman, who works at Alliance Brewing Company in Knoxville, Tenn., knew cash was going to be tight for a while. Although her brewery has stayed open for takeout, she has worked fewer hours and business is down. When a friend, Angie Ervin, started a local bartering group on Facebook, Ms. Coffman was eager to join.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: A Hospital Forgot to Bill Her Coronavirus Test. It Cost Her $1,980.
description: Send us your medical bills. We’ll use them to investigate hospital and doctor billing practices.
content: The New York Times is investigating the costs associated with testing and treatment for the coronavirus and how the pandemic is changing health care in America. You can read more about the project and submit your medical bills here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian
title: C.E.O.s call for more aid for small businesses.
description: More than 100 current and former chief executives called for more aid to small businesses in the United States in a letter sent to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin on Monday.
content: More than 100 current and former chief executives called for more aid to small businesses in the United States in a letter sent to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: South African Jerky, and More, at New York Biltong
description: The West Village store also ships nationwide.
content: Biltong is South African beef jerky, succulent and less stringy than the American kind, and this new West Village food store specializes in it. The house biltong is made from traditional grass-fed or aged beef, among other options, and thin little slices often have a richness that’s worthy of a platter or cheese board. The owners of the shop, Camran St. Luce and Brittney Brothers, also sell meat pies, sausages, chutneys, South African beers and ciders, and other goods. Everything except beer and cider is available nationwide on the website. The shop opens Aug. 4.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Cooking as Craft
description: Brush up on the basics, or lean into something new, whether it’s ginger-lime chicken or a pork schnitzel with quick pickles.
content: Good morning. “Manual competence” is the ideal Matthew Crawford speaks up for in his excellent 2010 book, “Shop Class as Soulcraft: An Inquiry Into the Value of Work.” Crawford’s a mechanic and a philosopher. He has no truck with craftsmanship or artistry. He speaks instead for the importance of trade work — “work that is meaningful because it is genuinely useful,” he writes. He finds that work engaging intellectually, and he finds in it an argument that celebrates responsibility and personal agency. (He’s a philosopher, remember.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Small Businesses Got Emergency Loans, but Not What They Expected
description: The S.B.A.’s disaster relief program allows for loans of up to $2 million. But now they’re capped at $150,000 — and agency officials are saying little about why.
content: For nearly 70 years, the Small Business Administration’s disaster relief program has helped companies recover from catastrophes including wildfires, hurricanes and earthquakes. But it has never faced anything like the coronavirus crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Google Pixel 4A Review: At $350, a Win for Those on a Budget
description: Yes, you can now pay less than $399 for a smartphone — and it won’t stink.
content: People generally adore Google for bringing useful technology to the masses at an aggressively low price, if not free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere, Katie Thomas, Noah Weiland, Peter Baker and Annie Karni
title: Scientists Worry About Political Influence Over Coronavirus Vaccine Project
description: Operation Warp Speed has moved along at a rapid clip. But some people involved in the process fear pressure to deliver an October surprise for President Trump.
content: In April, with hospitals overwhelmed and much of the United States in lockdown, the Department of Health and Human Services produced a presentation for the White House arguing that rapid development of a coronavirus vaccine was the best hope to control the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Unemployed Stare Into the Abyss. Republicans Look Away.
description: The cruelty and ignorance of Trump and his allies are creating another gratuitous disaster.
content: In case you haven’t noticed, the coronavirus is still very much with us. Around a thousand Americans are dying from Covid-19 each day, 10 times the rate in the European Union. Thanks to our failure to control the pandemic, we’re still suffering from Great Depression levels of unemployment; a brief recovery driven by premature attempts to resume business as usual appears to have petered out as states pause or reverse their opening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Will Congress Act on Covid Soon? ‘I’m Not Optimistic’
description: Money for the Postal Service and mail voting is one sticking point: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: The debate continues over the coronavirus stimulus, and Joe Arpaio, 88, comes back on the scene (yes, really). It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Would Microsoft Do With TikTok?
description: The potential blockbuster deal could go a few different ways.
content: Our next DealBook Debrief call is with Nikole Hannah-Jones, the creator of The 1619 Project, who will discuss racial injustice and corporate America, as well as take your questions. R.S.V.P. here to join the call on Thursday, Aug. 6 at 11 a.m. Eastern. And a programming note: DealBook is taking a short summer break, so you’ll next hear from us on Wednesday — and then we hope to see you on the call on Thursday — before normal service resumes next week. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: How TikTok’s Owner Tried, and Failed, to Cross the U.S.-China Divide
description: The founder of ByteDance, Zhang Yiming, dreamed of building a global tech company based in China. Then the geopolitical reality set in.
content: The Chinese entrepreneur behind TikTok took ample precautions when he set out to straddle the tech world’s most treacherous divide: the one separating China’s tightly controlled internet from the rest of the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Chinatown Is Coming Back, One Noodle at a Time
description: Restaurants in the Manhattan neighborhood suffered early in the pandemic. Some are just now experimenting with outdoor service.
content: With an amber chip of roast duck skin on one street and a tangle of lo mein on another, Chinatown took a few steps out of its long hibernation last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Gymnasts Worldwide Push Back on Their Sport’s Culture of Abuse
description: On Instagram and other social networks, gymnasts have tagged posts with #GymnastAlliance to share their own experiences in the wake of a new documentary that highlights verbal and physical abuse by coaches.
content: A culture in gymnastics that has tolerated coaches belittling, manipulating and in some cases physically abusing young athletes is being challenged by Olympians and other gymnasts around the world after an uprising in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Trump Dismisses 2 T.V.A. Board Members After Outsourcing Dispute
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority, an electric utility, quickly said it would reconsider its move to shift some work to contractors outside the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump abruptly announced on Monday the firing of two members of the Tennessee Valley Authority’s board of directors and demanded that the electric utility’s chief executive reverse what he said was a decision to outsource workers to other countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: The Mask Slackers of 1918
description: As the influenza pandemic swept across the United States in 1918 and 1919, masks took a role in political and cultural wars.
content: The masks were called muzzles, germ shields and dirt traps. They gave people a “pig-like snout.” Some people snipped holes in their masks to smoke cigars. Others fastened them to dogs in mockery. Bandits used them to rob banks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: One-Third of New York’s Small Businesses May Be Gone Forever
description: Small-business owners said they have exhausted federal and local assistance and see no end in sight after months of sharp revenue drops. Now, many are closing their shops and restaurants for good.
content: In early March, Glady’s, a Caribbean restaurant in Brooklyn, was bringing in about $35,000 a week in revenue. The Bank Street Bookstore, a 50-year-old children’s shop in Manhattan, was preparing for busy spring and summer shopping seasons. And Busy Bodies, a play space for children in Brooklyn, had just wrapped up months of packed classes with long waiting lists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel Says It Hit Bombers on Syrian Boundary
description: The military released grainy, edited footage of the ambush of what it said were four militants planting explosives in the area, amid heightened tensions along Israel’s northern frontiers.
content: JERUSALEM — Israeli troops ambushed four militants as they planted bombs along Israel’s boundary with Syria around midnight, the Israeli military said early Monday, amid heightened tensions along Israel’s frontiers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: In This Pandemic Summer, Don’t Forget About Kids’ Other Risks
description: Reinforcing summer safety with some of the special twists and dangers of this dangerous and twisty time.
content: I’m not sure whether to call this the good news or the bad news, but Covid-19 is not the only thing that parents need to think about right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Death of a Cat
description: For weeks, I have been trying to understand my own tears in the presence of a dying creature I did not love.
content: NASHVILLE — I first saw it in bits — two paws here, the tip of a tail there — on grainy, black-and-white images taken by our backyard trail camera. Normally that device captures only the wild animals you’d expect to find in a first-ring suburb: opossums, mainly, but also rabbits and raccoons and rat snakes, sometimes an owl, now and then a fox. I once saw a bobcat slink across our street, but it’s never shown up in the trail-cam photos. My heart lifted when I first saw a clearly feline haunch in one of the pictures, but the scale was all wrong for a bobcat. It was just an ordinary house cat, prowling in my backyard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Adam Max, Patron of Brooklyn Cultural Institutions, Dies at 62
description: He was chairman of the Brooklyn Academy of Music and a benefactor of St. Ann’s Warehouse. He and his wife also helped create a center for women’s history.
content: Adam Max, an investment manager who became a leading patron of Brooklyn cultural institutions, notably the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where he had been board chairman since 2017, died on July 27 at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 62.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Aaron Judge Is Nearly Unstoppable. He Thinks He Can Be Better.
description: Judge has hit home runs in five consecutive games, and he’s done it without one of his favorite tools: the video replay room.
content: Six home runs over five games is more than enough proof that a batter is locked in at the plate. But the Yankees star outfielder Aaron Judge, perhaps guided by humility or a constant search for perfection, insisted it was not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: Poland’s Supreme Court Declares Presidential Election Valid
description: The decision comes after supporters of the opposition candidate filed protests questioning the narrow victory for the incumbent, Andrzej Duda.
content: Poland’s Supreme Court on Monday upheld the results of President Andrzej Duda’s narrow victory in presidential elections last month, the country’s closest contest since the fall of communism in 1989, a decision that clears the path for the country’s conservative Law and Justice party to continue in power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Allyson Waller
title: Private Boats Enter SpaceX Splashdown Area, Raising Concerns
description: “We need to do a better job next time” of securing the area, the NASA administrator, Jim Bridenstine, said.
content: Two American astronauts were greeted by a group of private boats on Sunday as their SpaceX capsule splashed down safely in the Gulf of Mexico, an encroachment that distracted from an otherwise triumphant milestone for the country’s resurgent space program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: John Eric Swing, a Filipino-American Community Builder, Dies at 48.
description: Mr. Swing was a catalyst in the Historic Filipinotown neighborhood of Los Angeles, a new center of food start-ups. He died of complications of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: For the Navajo Nation, a Fight for Better Food Gains New Urgency
description: As the pandemic has brought home the importance of the global movement for food sovereignty, members are planting and sharing.
content: THE NAVAJO NATION — When Summer Brown lived in Phoenix, she had no problem finding fresh produce. If the Sprouts supermarket near her home didn’t have what she was looking for, she would just drive somewhere else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Dean
title: I’d Need Evidence Before I Got a Covid-19 Vaccine. It Doesn’t Exist Yet.
description: Scientists need to show us the data. And that’s exactly what they’re working on.
content: Coronavirus vaccines are rapidly advancing through the development pipeline. The University of Oxford’s vaccine is in large trials in Britain, Brazil and South Africa. In the United States, researchers just began enrolling around 30,000 volunteers to test Moderna’s vaccine, and more trials are starting every day. Operation Warp Speed has set an ambitious goal of delivering 300 million doses of a safe, effective vaccine by January.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Stretched by a Summer of Scourge, and Now a Storm
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 3, 2020.
content: “It’s just kind of been the way 2020’s gone so far. But we roll with it, right?”
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: August 3, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, August 3, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, August 3, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Digital School Cookbook to Aid Families
description: Martin Van Buren High School in Queens Village is raising money with a collaborative digital cookbook.
content: There’s a story to be told about Martin Van Buren High School in Queens Village. Less than a decade ago, the graduation rate at the school was 46 percent. With the arrival of a new principal, Sam Sochet, the situation began to improve. Last year, the rate was nearly 80 percent, and the curriculum has been bolstered with programs in law, engineering, robotics, science and humanities. Now, the alumni are raising money to support students’ families — in partnership with CommonPoint of Queens, a social service organization — through a digital cookbook: “Comfort Food From Around the World: Recipes by Students, Staff, Alumni and Friends of MVB.” The global collection of 168 recipes includes one from the chef Yotam Ottolenghi, and can be downloaded for free, though there is an appeal for donations. It has raised nearly $40,000 from individuals and corporate sponsors since it was released on June 11. Steve Wilson, an alumnus who is spearheading the campaign and edited the book, said that they would soon release the current edition in Spanish, and that they were planning for a second volume. Some of the recipes in the current book include Filipino lumpia, Egyptian mulukhiyah soup, Finnish meat pies, and kugel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: What Happened to the Young Voters Focused on Guns?
description: It’s not their top issue anymore, but many see it as a part of other, larger concerns.
content: After the mass shooting in 2018 at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School left 17 people dead in Parkland, Fla., the massacre’s young survivors converted their outrage into political organizing. Alongside other student leaders across the country, they brought hundreds of thousands of people to Washington for the March for Our Lives, pressed the case for tougher gun laws in the Florida legislature and at the U.S. Senate, registered 50,000 new voters nationally, and helped drive a surge in turnout by young people in that year’s midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Stephenie Meyer Is Telling Edward’s Story, Even if It Makes Her Anxious
description: The best-selling author talks about her latest book, “Midnight Sun,” which retells “Twilight” from the vampire’s perspective. Why now? “Because I finished it,” she says.
content: When Stephenie Meyer decided this year to release “Midnight Sun,” a retelling of her best-selling “Twilight” novel from the vampire’s point of view, she thought: “No one can possibly care about it anymore.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shanicia Boswell
title: How to Diversify Your Toy Box
description: Ways to create a multiracial and multicultural spectrum in a child’s activities and toys.
content: Becoming a mother made me reflect on my own childhood and how I was raised to view diversity. I grew up in South Georgia at a time when dolls of my complexion were not easy to find. So I played with mostly white dolls. The features I observed in Ken and Barbie were exactly what I saw around me: the familiar aspect of white people. My doctor was white. My teachers were mostly white. Police officers and bank tellers all had skin that did not look like my own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Dirt Candy Returns With a Vegetarian Muffuletta
description: The chef Amanda Cohen’s vegetarian restaurant on the Lower East Side has reopened with a new menu.
content: Dirt Candy, the chef Amanda Cohen’s vegetarian restaurant on the Lower East Side, has emerged four months after closing. Her new menu includes a vegetarian version of a muffuletta sandwich. Smoked celeriac never made it into the classic from Central Grocery in New Orleans. But here, it’s among the paper-thin layers of vegetables like eggplant, zucchini and carrot interspersed with pickled stuff, vegan provolone and yuba (tofu skin), and olive tapenade in a successful creation. It’s sold for takeout and delivery, and there are socially distant seats on the sidewalk for instant gratification.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Dark, Brooding Rum for Your Cocktails
description: Santa Teresa in Venezuela has been making the liquor since 1796.
content: Santa Teresa, an elegant rum estate established not far from Caracas, Venezuela, in 1796, is still going strong. Its Santa Teresa 1796 Solera Rum — processed using the solera method, like sherry, and aged in bourbon oak barrels, whiskey oak barrels and French limousin oak barrels — has a dark, brooding complexity best enjoyed in a snifter. The liquor’s bold character will also shine through in a drink like rum and pineapple. During the pandemic, Geoff Robinson, a company manager, enlisted bartenders to participate in designing a new “Crafted Together Limited Edition” label for the rum. The label is royal blue and gold with a subtle mosaic of images selected by about 25 bartenders in exquisite corpse fashion, with each participant nominating the next, and so forth. The company also donated $10,000 to the Bartender Emergency Assistance Program by the nonprofit United States Bartenders’ Guild.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: A Vast Racial Gap in Death Penalty Cases, New Study Finds
description: Defendants convicted of killing white people, the study found, were far more likely to be executed than the killers of Black people.
content: WASHINGTON — Black lives do not matter nearly as much as white ones when it comes to the death penalty, a new study has found. Building on data at the heart of a landmark 1987 Supreme Court decision, the study concluded that defendants convicted of killing white victims were executed at a rate 17 times greater than those convicted of killing Black victims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andria Hautamaki
title: A Visit to 5 of Patagonia’s Most Remote Schoolhouses
description: Community life within the isolated villages of southern Chile is facilitated in part by an unlikely source: a network of rural schools.
content: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Andria Hautamaki shares a collection of images from rural Patagonia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Turkish Aggression Is NATO’s ‘Elephant in the Room’
description: Despite being a NATO member, Turkey has bought Russian air defense. And a recent push into Libya and its energy ambitions nearly led to armed conflicts with France and Greece.
content: BRUSSELS — The warships were escorting a vessel suspected of smuggling weapons into Libya, violating a United Nations arms embargo. Challenged by a French naval frigate, the warships went to battle alert. Outnumbered and outgunned, the French frigate withdrew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Navy Investigates Video of Dogs Attacking Man in Kaepernick Jersey
description: The Navy condemned the video, which it said was taken at an “independent organization’s event” last year. A filmmaker said it took place at a museum dedicated to the SEALs.
content: The U.S. Navy command that oversees the SEALs is investigating a video of dogs attacking a man in a Colin Kaepernick jersey at a 2019 event in Florida, the authorities said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Hiroko Masuike
title: Stimulus Stalemate, Medical Bills, TikTok: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: A project in Kentucky aims to show how home lending can build wealth.
description: Homeownership is a crucial part of a family’s ability to build wealth: A home is the largest asset for most American families, and the value it can gain over decades can be tapped during retirement or left to the next generation.
content: Homeownership is a crucial part of a family’s ability to build wealth: A home is the largest asset for most American families, and the value it can gain over decades can be tapped during retirement or left to the next generation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Rubin
title: The Wild Story of Creem, Once ‘America’s Only Rock ’n’ Roll Magazine’
description: A new documentary traces the rise and fall of the irreverent, boundary-smashing music publication where Lester Bangs did some of his most famous work.
content: On Jaan Uhelszki’s first day at Creem magazine in October 1970, she met a fellow new hire: Lester Bangs, a freelance writer freshly arrived from California to fill the post of record reviews editor. His plaid three-piece suit made him look like an awkward substitute teacher, she thought, and certainly out of place among the hippies and would-be revolutionaries using the publication’s decrepit Detroit office as a crash pad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick and Sanam Yar
title: What Has Changed Since George Floyd
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: In Washington, the efforts to reform policing have stalled. Congress can’t agree on a bill and has largely stopped debating the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: This Tool Could Protect Your Photos From Facial Recognition
description: Researchers at the University of Chicago want you to be able to post selfies without worrying that the next Clearview AI will use them to identify you.
content: In recent years, companies have been prowling the web for public photos associated with people’s names that they can use to build enormous databases of faces and improve their facial recognition systems, adding to a growing sense that personal privacy is being lost, bit by digital bit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Vaccine Race, Donald Trump, SpaceX: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The school year is underway in some parts of the United States — and we’re already seeing how fraught reopening classrooms can be.
content: The school year is underway in some parts of the United States — and we’re already seeing how fraught reopening classrooms can be:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Astor
title: Bernaldina José Pedro, Repository of Indigenous Culture, Dies at 75
description: Ms. Pedro was a leader of Brazil’s Macuxi people and carried a message of alarm for their fate to Pope Francis in 2018. She died of the novel coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: ‘I Am Scared’: Italian Sex Workers Face Poverty and Illness In the Pandemic
description: Prostitution is not illegal in Italy, nor is it regulated as an official occupation. But the coronavirus has forced many sex workers to accept certain risks in order to avoid poverty.
content: MILAN — When the mayor of Modica, a Sicilian town known for its chocolates and churches, learned that a sex worker in the area had tested positive for the coronavirus, he immediately started to worry about an outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh and Shawn Hubler
title: As the Coronavirus Comes to School, a Tough Choice: When to Close
description: As schools in the South and the Midwest reopen this week, officials must decide what steps to take as staff members and students test positive.
content: More than 200 employees have been barred from work in Georgia’s largest school district. A high school in Indiana had to shift to online learning after just two days. And students in Mississippi were forced to quarantine after classmates tested positive for the coronavirus during the first week of classes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Taking a Spear Into the Sea, and Washing Anxiety Away
description: I kept seeing people in Sydney carry spearguns to and from the ocean. To understand why, I held my breath and dived in.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — Emma Shearman held her speargun and focused on her breathing. In, out, relax, she thought. Deep and steady, as rhythmic as the waves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Dementia on the Retreat in the U.S. and Europe
description: Rates of dementia have steadily fallen over the past 25 years, a new study finds. But the disease is increasingly common in some parts of the world.
content: Despite the lack of effective treatments or preventive strategies, the dementia epidemic is on the wane in the United States and Europe, scientists reported on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Tepper
title: 4 Simple Ways to Take Control of Your Coronavirus Budget
description: The pandemic has changed the way we budget. Here’s some advice to get back on track.
content: Budgeting is never an easy task, but keeping tabs on your money has become especially difficult over the past few months. About 30 million Americans are collecting jobless benefits, and more than a million new people file for unemployment each week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adelle Waldman
title: Welcome to Another Novel Set in Brooklyn. This One Is Different.
description: In “Kings County,” David Goodwillie examines New York’s most celebrated borough with an uncynical eye.
content: KINGS COUNTYBy David Goodwillie
source.name: The New York Times

title: Hurricane Makes Landfall in North Carolina
description: Isaias regained strength into a Category 1 hurricane on Monday night, bringing heavy winds and rain to the East Coast. Flash flooding and tornadoes are possible.
content: Hurricane Isaias made landfall in southern North Carolina late Monday night, hours after strengthening into a Category 1 hurricane. Forecasters warned of heavy rainfall and powerful winds as the storm travels up the East Coast, and flash floods, storm surges and even tornadoes are possible, the National Hurricane Center said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Newell-Hanson
title: A Home Inscribed With the History of Venice Beach
description: Within a storied Los Angeles studio complex, Karina Deyko and David de Rothschild have built an eclectic, freewheeling space in which to live and work.
content: While the British environmentalist David de Rothschild was at sea in the spring of 2010, crossing the Pacific Ocean on the Plastiki — a 60-foot catamaran built primarily from recycled bottles — to raise awareness about the climate crisis, the actress Karina Deyko, his wife, made her own voyage of discovery. She had recently met, through a mutual friend in Los Angeles, the actress Kelly Reilly and the photographer Guy Webster, who helped establish the tenets of rock ’n’ roll portraiture in the 1960s with his images of Jim Morrison and the Rolling Stones. Reilly had been renting a small apartment within Webster’s sprawling studio complex in Venice Beach but would soon be traveling to London to make a film. Webster wondered if Deyko wanted to come see the space and possibly sublet it. At the time, she was living in Echo Park, on the east side of the city, and “I knew that when David was done with the Plastiki he’d want to be by the beach,” Deyko says. So she took Webster up on his offer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Padma Lakshmi Wants Us to Eat More Adventurously
description: “There’s such a laziness about reaching for the thing that is most familiar.”
content: “There’s such a laziness about reaching for the thing that is most familiar.”
